Is anyone else just plain disturbed by the protests spreading across the Middle East over the cartoons of the prophet in several European papers? It's one thing for the West and the Middle East to have a back and forth discussion (which I fuly support, gods know, both sides are FAR from perfect). But when they start using death threats when people in the West use their freedom of speech and press? It's rediculous. They have a right to voice their opposition over the cartoons, but they do not have a right to make death threats against the cartoonists, journalists and papers themselves.

(Fiction)
 
 
 Bill Clinton on Muslims: 
 
 Federal Aviation Agency 
 800 Independence Avenue S.W. 
 Washington D.C. 20591 
 
 Dear Sirs: 
 
 I have the solution for the prevention of hijackings, and at the same time getting our airline industry back on its feet. 
 
 Since men of the Muslim religion are not allowed to look at naked women we should replace all of our female flight attendants with strippers who have huge juggs, camel toe *******, long legs, and tight arses. 
 
 Muslims would be afraid to get on the planes for fear of seeing a naked woman, and of course, every businessman in this country would start flying again in hope of seeing a naked woman. 
 
 We would have no more hijackings, and the airline industry would have record sales. 
 
 Now why didn't Congress think of this? 
 
 Sincerely, 
 
 William (Bill) Jefferson Clinton 
 P.S. - Don't tell Hillary about this letter

Many of the publishers of these cartoons, and probably the artist himself, was out to offend people and make crude stereotypes.

1. The cartoons are the product of one man or a few men, yet the rioters insist on torching embassies and flags, which are usually protests against governments. You would think they'd put out a hit on the one man, like they did with Salman Rushdie.
 
 
 
 2. The rioters do not seem to see the irony of protesting the depiction of Islam as a violent religion by rioting in the streets, torching embassies, and holding signs that say "Behead those who insult Islam." 
 
 
 
 
 3. The protests come months after the cartoons were printed and circulated, which makes them appear as if they were timed to coincide with something else entirely and the cartoons themselves are simply an excuse.

You have to wonder how many people have actually even seen these cartoons, especially as I can't see many of the riotings muslims speaking Danish, let alone having a subscription to a danish magazine. The press on both sides I think are at the very least partly responsible for blowing this out of proportion in an attempt to make news.

Thus by portraying the prophet in a cartoon, wheter good or bad, the beliefs of the people were violated. In addition, the cartoons can be considered to be insulting by many Muslims- their views and beliefs are different from others. 
 
 I also learnt the the Government of Denmark refuses to comment on the issue citing Freedon of Speech. From my understanding, no one human right has preference over another and the right to practise one's religion free from contempt is a Human Right. While Freedon os Speech is indeed important and should be allowed, it must be remembered that Freedon of Speech does not mean freedom from being responsible.

 Firstly, I am a Hindu and I am hopeful that the comment on Hindus and Shintoism is a sarcastic one.
 
 Your point is noted that what is required in other faiths may not be required by your faith. Thus if being of one religion requires a certain diet, I cannot hold it against anyone who is not obligated to have that diet as so as well. 
 
 However, it is different if someone does something that can be perceived to be a direct attack, or as a taunt about my views. I should then be entitled to voice a defense and even protest. 
 
 The cartoons drawn are considered by many Muslims and even non- Muslims as being insensitive and of a poor taste. By portraying the Prophet, whose teachings gave rise to the religion as we know it today; one can even consider this to be an attack on the very core of Islam.
 
 Many Muslims today, whether they live in the east or west feel that others feel that others, in particular those in the west look at them like a threat to life. Since 9/11 they have faced discrimination of various levels. Thus, it is only natural that they may take these cartoons extremely seriously. These cartoons strike them at their core.
 
 Today (09 - 02- 2006), I read that yet another European newspaper has published the cartoons, despite knowing that they have sparked protests all over the world, some being violent. This is like throwing fuel on the already blazing flames of anger. Can this be viewed as an attempt to disregard the views of the protesters?
 In History, we find that the end of the Inca civilization resulted when Atualpa, the Inca emperor, threw the Bible on the floor. Pizarro and his men considered this to be a great insult and destroyed the entire race of people. To the Incas, the book was just a trivial piece of literature but to the Europeans it was the core of their faith - all their beliefs revolved around what was written there.
 
 To acknowledge that the cartoons have hurt Muslims all over the world unnecessarily and simply apologize for the pain caused by them is no difficult task. It is a fact that not all Muslims wear bombs and cause havoc. In fact some of the persons who commit such deeds may even be non Muslims.

There is no PROOF of "God or Allah" therefore how can a man be the last prophet to mankind from "God"? Are you telling me "God/Allah" is a sexist discriminating pig that only believe MEN can spread the message of "God". Gimme a break. 
 
 I'm not a religious NUT, and no MAN is a prophet as far as I'm concerned, and if I want to draw a painting of the Muhammad like a Picasso, then I will. What's next with religion, will I be forbidden to draw a picture of demons for fear of bad luck.
 
 PROVE TO ME THERE IS A GOD. Be secure in your religion as I am in mine. I'm tired of all the religious faith trying to prove their faith is more supreme. 
 
 I am solid in my "beliefs". My beliefs have no absurd LAWS dictating to others how to live and not to live. That's not GOD that's a religious male leader! 
 
 Why is it only HUMANS have "gods", thank god, cows, horses, pigs, dogs and cats don't have their version of "gods" that would be a holy mess. 
 
 You see when natural disasters hit its not an act of god. When countries rape and kill their own citizens, that is not the act of their god. When countries abuse the environment and the earth is becoming damaged, that's not an act of their god. When the dinosaurs were wiped out, that wasn't an act of their god. Believe what you all want, believe a cartoon of a MAN with a turban with a bomb is "insulting", to YOUR god, but what is really insulting is that you think I have to obey the laws of YOUR god, your prophets and your messengers.
 
 Well, let me tell you about MY RELIGION. "No man or woman will make claim to being a prophet, or messenger, from a greater being, to do so would mock the intelligence of human kind. Where the fate of humans, and all living matter on earth is in the hands of humans" 
 
 Now, am I not entitled to call out the con-men of other faiths with "gods" and "prophets", or must my religion cower to yours?
